bestBHT.bht: Jesus, after offering one sacrifice for sins forever, sat down on the right hand of God, waiting for his enemies to be placed as footstool under his feet. This second advent is not a break in his waiting, but the last step before the subjection of his enemies. His one sacrifice will continue as the only oblation forever, disproving the mass. To repeat his sacrifice would be dishonoring to it. Jesus accomplished what the many failed to do, offering one sacrifice forever and now awaits its eternal result.

Henry Alford: having offered one sacrifice for sins for ever
sat down on the right hand of God; henceforth waiting until his enemies be placed as footstool of his feet
The second advent is no break in Christ’s waiting till his enemies be subdued to him, but it is the last step but one of that subjection
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: The offering of Christ, once for all made, will continue the one and only oblation for ever; no other will supersede it.
The mass, which professes to be the frequent repetition of one and the same sacrifice of Christ's body, is hence disproved.
A repetition would imply that the former once-for-all offering of the one sacrifice was imperfect, and so would be dishonoring to it.
Albert Barnes: But this man - The Lord Jesus.
After he had offered one sacrifice for sins - By dying on the cross.
He will no more submit himself to scenes of suffering and death to expiate human guilt.
Marvin Vincent: Forever [εις το διηνεκες] . Const. with offered.
It is according to the usage of the epistle to place this phrase after that which it qualifies.
He offered one sacrifice forever, and then sat down, awaiting its eternal result.
Philip Schaff: But he (this Priest) having offered one sacrifice for sins forever, took his seat on the right hand of God, an evidence of the completeness of His work."
His priesthood indeed continues, and the presentation of His sacrifice 'the perpetual oblation;' but His atoning work is over."
For ever,' in perpetuity, uninterruptedly, may be connected with 'took His seat,' but the usage of this Epistle is to connect it with the words that precede.
Archibald T. Robertson: The one sacrifice does the work that the many failed to do.
One wonders how priests who claim that the 'mass' is the sacrifice of Christ's body repeated explain this verse.
For ever. Can be construed either with μιαν θυσιαν or with εκαθισεν.
John Gill: Jesus Christ, for he is a man, though not a mere man.
He sits enjoying rest, ease, and pleasure, and that for ever.
His sacrifice being effectual to take away sin when theirs was not.
John Wesley: But he — The virtue of whose one sacrifice remains for ever.
Sat down — As a son, in majesty and honour.

bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus, after offering one sacrifice for sins forever, took his seat on the right hand of God, waiting until his enemies are placed as footstool of his feet. This second advent is not a break in his waiting, but the last step before the subjection of his enemies. His one sacrifice will continue as the one and only oblation forever, disproving the doctrine of the mass. To repeat his sacrifice would imply imperfection and dishonor to it. Jesus accomplished what the many failed to do, offering one sacrifice forever and then sitting down, awaiting its eternal result. His priesthood continues, but his atoning work is complete and his seat on the right hand of God is evidence of its completeness.

Jesus, having offered one sacrifice for sins forever, sat down on the right hand of God, waiting for his enemies to be placed as a footstool under his feet. This second advent is not a break in his waiting but the second-to-last step of subjugating his enemies. His one sacrifice will continue as the only oblation forever, disproving the idea of recurring sacrifices like the mass. To repeat his sacrifice would dishonor its perfection. Jesus achieved what the many couldn't, offering one sacrifice forever, and now awaits its eternal result.

Jesus offered one sacrifice for sins forever and then sat down on the right hand of God, patiently awaiting the moment when his enemies will be made a footstool under his feet. This second advent is not a disruption in his waiting but the penultimate step in his triumph over his enemies. His one sacrifice will always remain the sole and perfect oblation, disproving the notion of repetitive sacrifices like the mass. Any attempt to repeat his sacrifice would be dishonoring to its perfection.

Jesus, after offering one sacrifice for sins forever, sat down on the right hand of God, waiting for his enemies to be placed as footstool under his feet. This second advent is not a break in his waiting, but the last step before the subjection of his enemies. His one sacrifice will continue as the only oblation forever, disproving the mass. To repeat his sacrifice would be dishonoring to it. Jesus accomplished what the many failed to do, offering one sacrifice forever and now awaits its eternal result.

Jesus offered one sacrifice for sins forever and then sat down on the right hand of God, waiting for his enemies to be placed as a footstool under his feet. His one sacrifice will continue as the only oblation forever, disproving the mass. To repeat his sacrifice would dishonor its perfection. Jesus accomplished what the many failed to do, offering one sacrifice forever and now awaits its eternal result.
